defect.translation[0].definitions[0].def: a fault or a lack of something that means that something or someone is not perfect
defect.translation[0].definitions[0].exa: All the cars are tested for defects before they leave the factory.
defect.translation[0].note_box[0].sectio: The movie has a few serious defects.
They have found a major defect in the program.
There are one or two minor defects on the car’s paintwork.
Doctors examined the baby and could find no physical defects.
Older buildings are bound to have some structural defects.
The condition is caused by a genetic defect.
About 11% of children have birth defects.
Laura was born with a rare heart defect.
He had a speech defect which made it quite difficult to understand him.
Laziness was just one of his character defects.
The old system had some serious defects.
She had surgery to correct a defect in her right eye.
defect.translation[1].definitions[0].def: to leave your own country or group in order to go to or join an opposing one
defect.translation[1].definitions[0].exa: a Russian actor who defected to the West
defect.translation[2].definitions[0].def: a fault in something that means it is not perfect
defect.translation[2].definitions[0].exa: They recalled the vehicles because of brake defects.
an effort to improve customer satisfaction and reduce product defects
a possible safety defect with the plane’s autopilot
defect.translation[3].definitions[0].def: if the buyer of one product defects to another product, they stop buying the first one and start buying the second one
defect.translation[3].definitions[0].exa: They tried to retain customers who might defect to a credit card with a lower interest rate.
defect.translation[3].definitions[1].def: if an employee working for a particular company defects, they leave it and start working for another
defect.translation[3].definitions[1].exa: Although several senior employees have defected, it’s not true that there’s any kind of mass walkout.
